item.title: Multiple comparison
item.description:
Let say you have a data set with many columns and you would like to see if there are is any statistically significant dependence between some of the parameters. Just write a script and find those with p < 0.05 - right?

Actually no… You are almost guarantied to have at least 5% of those columns to be statistically significantly correlated. This is known as a “multiple comparison” problem.

The problem is known

An example

Make a data frame

Randomly generated 100 columns of 1e5 elements

set.seed(123)

library(tidyverse)
df <- tibble(V1 = runif(1e5))

for(i in 2:100)
  df[[paste0("V", i)]] <- runif(1e5)

Correlations

Let me calculate correlations of the 1st with all the other columns, and then extract a p-value

res <- sapply(2:100, function(i){
  cor.test(df[["V1"]], df[[paste0("V", i)]])$p.value
})

# if you would like to do the same with a linear model
# res <- sapply(2:100, function(i){
#   mod <- lm(df[["V1"]] ~ df[[paste0("V", i)]])
#   summary(mod)$coefficients[2, 4]
# })

res
##  [1] 0.208857842 0.787683654 0.183882152 0.341214093 0.411887870
##  [6] 0.363300463 0.105245125 0.453033654 0.157776986 0.111031320
## [11] 0.434434104 0.375520191 0.850306795 0.953865868 0.905601495
## [16] 0.763973248 0.009781952 0.267155852 0.633299729 0.930786113
## [21] 0.808576997 0.638890361 0.353047377 0.796047068 0.325107555
## [26] 0.801957074 0.563934781 0.941046950 0.772066202 0.368054271
## [31] 0.873451800 0.294747263 0.452035679 0.796113472 0.599931204
## [36] 0.258693453 0.191503669 0.691955671 0.045081214 0.569269362
## [41] 0.179901102 0.810782314 0.331447275 0.757848341 0.713440607
## [46] 0.572720082 0.330560072 0.861100052 0.618168456 0.806936198
## [51] 0.056087926 0.343356728 0.639003906 0.761278315 0.196175372
## [56] 0.743768302 0.730764603 0.436477225 0.560039632 0.915270411
## [61] 0.715804689 0.714595150 0.836210015 0.660225939 0.258330777
## [66] 0.495893821 0.167267256 0.621885926 0.530513361 0.570584308
## [71] 0.717389208 0.196029864 0.652257825 0.375548476 0.812282034
## [76] 0.816542910 0.463594178 0.133681358 0.350936828 0.200120205
## [81] 0.346320930 0.755064242 0.543012780 0.281395566 0.177204811
## [86] 0.465263299 0.865361874 0.195236199 0.004776466 0.865152420
## [91] 0.424794023 0.342671717 0.020180190 0.012159762 0.882157414
## [96] 0.927610375 0.354376533 0.574848895 0.748248143

How many significant?

How many of these p-values are “statistically significant”? (p-values < 0.05)

sum(res < 0.05)
## [1] 5

Let me print summary for the first of such models

ind <- which(res < 0.05) + 1 # +1 because in sapply we start with 2
sub_df <- df[, c(1, ind)]

cor.test(df[["V1"]], df[[paste0("V", ind[1])]])
## 
##  Pearson's product-moment correlation
## 
## data:  df[["V1"]] and df[[paste0("V", ind[1])]]
## t = 2.5835, df = 99998, p-value = 0.009782
## alternative hypothesis: true correlation is not equal to 0
## 95 percent confidence interval:
##  0.001971667 0.014366768
## sample estimates:
##         cor 
## 0.008169531

Plot those with p values of < 0.05

library(ggplot2)
library(gridExtra)

sub_df <- sub_df %>%
  gather(key = other_var, value = value, -V1)

ggplot(sub_df) +
  geom_smooth(aes(x = value, y = V1), method = "lm") +
  facet_wrap(~other_var) +
  scale_x_continuous(breaks = c(0, 0.5, 1))

Outcome

Well… within 100 randomly generated variables we found 5 correlations which have a p-value which is less than 0.05. There are many examples of that mistake: for instance here.

Solutions

  • formulate a hypothesis about variables relation before collecting data and test only this relation

  • apply correction

    • Bonferroni_correction - divide threshold for statistical significance by the number of comparisons (0.05 / 5, if there are 5 comparisons)
    • Holm-Bonferroni is a better method then Boneferroni to control familywise error rate - it is a default method for p.adjust function in R

  • A more detailed discussion here

  • If you have a lot of data, use only small part of it (random selection). Then use other part of data to test findings.

  • What about machine learning and fitting parameters? No problem there - read here

  • A completelly different approach - Bayesian perspective

item.title: Experimental labs with computer simulations
item.description:
While teaching laboratories for calculus-based Physics I figured out there is no teaching curriculum available which would combine actual experiments with computer (or also called numerical) simulations. So, I developed a sequence of 7 lab modules to implement exactly that.

Motivation

Computer simulations are now everywhere. Complexity of many real system does not allow to obtain a model written through analytic equations. In such situations numerical simulations provide a good (if not the only one) way to do address them.

Computer simulations allow people to perform weather forecasting, understand dynamics of star clusters, enhance particle physics research, allow to perform simulations of chemical interactions, as well as address many other systems.

So… why don’t we teach students to use simulations?

Description

The developed curriculum is composed from modules - each module uses both simulations and experiments to address a phenomena under study, and lasts for 3 weeks (21 weeks total for the whole set).

Wolfram Mathematica was chosen as a language for computer because it provides an easy to understand, follow (and modify) way to perform fairly good numerical simulations without a need of teaching students a full scale programming class.

Topics are:

  • Motion with a drag
  • Pendulum with an arbitrary amplitude
  • Magnus effect
  • Centripetal force acting on a pendulum
  • A ball rolling from paths of various shapes
  • Doppler shift and Fourier transformation
  • Equipotential lines.

Students generally only have a task setup by a teacher and some “starter code”. They have to develop an experiment and perform it by themselves. They also have to write the full simulation code and then compare experiment results with simulations.

This set was taught for two years in a calculus-based Physics Class in the following settings: 40 minutes once a week of class time (plus time allocated by students for work outside of classroom), 3 weeks per module. Most students went through advanced open-ended algebra-based labs the year before and were ready to work with open ended tasks.

More details

  • preprint on arxiv.org
  • code on GitHub

item.title: About
item.description:
My interests include Physics, Data Science, Education.

In education I like designing a simplest possible way to deliver an idea, and create conditions for natural further development.

This blog presents a simplissimost introduction (as I see it) to topics or ideas. And some other stuff from time to time.

Short story

  • For my Master’s degree (theoretical Physics) I was playing with a behavior of a particle transitioning between potential wells. This was addressed using computer simulations in Matlab and Wolfram Mathematica.

  • Later I got interested in psychology, participated in some educational classes, which now, probably, influences my teaching a lot.

  • Then I went to work in IT, playing with algorithms for stock market trading (mostly using C).

  • For PhD degree (Physics) I was working on studying a growth mechanism of graphene-like (1 layer carbon film) films on a quartz substrate. Part of work - experiment, part - computer simulation using Quantum Espresso and CUNY high performance computer center resources.

  • After teaching Physics at City University of New York for several years I formed an impression, that introducing Physics to students at a college level may be much less efficient comparing to do doing that at a High School (I was introduced to Physics at 9th grade, and had some basis for comparison).

    • So I went to work at a High School to teach Physics. I focused on labs for core classes (algebra- and calculus-based) and on Quantum Mechanics
    • It appeared that having an opportunity to introduce research as part of a Physics curriculum is really beneficial for general kids’ understanding on how Physics works
    • At the high school I was (and am) working on 1) teaching kids stuff 2) preparing them to do research 3) mentoring them in their research activities
    • I did organize and do mentor lab on micro- and nano- technology
    • Quantum Mechanics class follows a college level book, starting with Dirac notation at the beginning - much better way comparing to wave mechanics (from my teaching experience)

  • While teaching Physics I also started learning/doing Data Science.

    • Coursera classes, projects on Kaggle, books, projects, etc
    • In 2016 I and a colleague organized a training program for PhDs at Columbia University
    • In 2017 I started teaching a full year class of Data Science for kids at a High School (see teaching page).
    • I also spend some time working as a consultant at NYC firms.

At this moment

I continue to teach Physics (theory, experiment, computer simulations), and Data Science, while also doing some projects and consulting as time allows

Tools I have being using

Data Science and Programming

R, R shiny, SQL, bash, Spark, H2O, C, Matlab, Wolfram Mathematica.
High performance computing(HPC), Density Functional Theory (DFT), Quantum ESPRESSO

Experimental Physics

CVD, MBE, photo-lithography, plasma and etching, sputtering, processing in clean room environment, AFM, SEM, spectroscopy, photo-lithography.

item.title: Teaching
item.description:
Physics

  • Algebra-based Physics (college and high school)
  • Calculus-based Physics (college and high school)
  • Quantum Mechanics (high school)
  • I did setup and now supervise a nanotechnology research laboratory at a high school
  • A course of labs designed to develop student’s research skill was developed and will be described soon
  • A course of labs combining numerical simulations with experiments which I developed is now availabe on arxiv.org. Link

Data Science

  • Data Science class I did introduce and teach at a high school
  • I did organize and now supervise Data Science research laboratory at a high school

Data Science I

Data Science I course is designed to teach students analyze data using R language, as well as how to present results of analysis. Data in the modern world are coming from different sources and in different formats. Data can be obtained from sensors, collected via a survey, stored in a database, or wait to be downloaded from Internet. Often such data will have a “messy” structure, there will be missing values, etc. Students will learn how to access data from various sources, reshape, organize and clean it. Basic statistical information and plots will be employed to make an initial exploratory analysis. We shall cover techniques for creation of highly customized professionally looking plots. Students will learn to create interactive plots and interactive web applications (using R Shiny), to present data visually to a wide auditory. Linear model will be used to perform a basic modeling. This class involves a lot of coding and practical exercises in R.
Textbook: R for Data Science: Import, Tidy, Transform, Visualize, and Model Data (Authors: Hadley Wickham, Garrett Grolemund)

Data Science II

covers selected topics of machine learning. When data is cleaned and understood (covered in Data Science I) it is possible to create a “prediction” model: calculate a projected salary, classify emails to spam or ham, find “clusters” of friends on Facebook, detect a fraud transaction on a credit card, etc. Students will obtain skills in doing regression, classification, clustering and anomaly detection. The following algorithms will be covered: k-nearest neighborhoods, linear model, logistic regression, LDA, QDA, polynomial regression, splines, GAMs, tree-based methods, SVM. The coverage will include resampling methods, regularization, principal components, text mining.
Textbook: An Introduction to Statistical Learning with Applications in R (Authors: James, G., Witten, D., Hastie, T., Tibshirani, R).

EDS training program

I (with two colleagues) developed and taught (in January and June of 2016) a 35-hours (5 days) “Essentials of Data Science” training program for PhD-students and Postdocs (twice at Columbia University). More details can be found here Ket Labs

item.title: Essentials of Data Science (with R)
item.description:
There is a lot of information on Data Science on Internet. On this page I summarize the most essential things you would need to know to start working on real projects. The rest you can figure out on the way. This page is intentionally short (relativelly).

Books

  • R for Data Science
  • An Introduction to Statistical Learning
  • Data Science for Business

Tools, Installation and updating

  • installr package

    • for updating R to a newer version (from RGui do installr::updateR())
    • installing Rtools, git, ImageMagick, etc. Link

  • devtools package for installation of packages from github repositories directly

Interactive dashboards

  • R Shiny
  • R Shiny Gallery
  • R Shiny themes

Cheatsheets

  • dplyr and tidyr, ggplot, shiny sheet 1, shiny sheet 2, regular expressions

Databases

  • sqlzoo, sql

Working with medium data

  • If data can still fit in RAM of local machine, but slow to process with dplyr, a package data.table can provide a faster alternative
    • vignettes

Working with Big data (located in cluster)

  • sparklyr: R interface for Apache Spark
  • rsparkling: Sparkling Water (H2O) Machine Learning, including deep learning
  • R with Hadoop
  • Visualize Large Data

Text mining in R

  • tm package
  • Text Mining with R (book)

Plotting libraries

  • ggplot2 - see R for Data Science. There are many extentions for ggplot2. Some of them are here:
    • gridExtra to allign plots
    • ggbio - can be usefull in order to allign several plots (instead of gridExtra)
    • ggmap to make plots with geographical maps
    • ggpubr - modified ggplot2 for publication ready plots
  • plotly - makes ggplot2 interactive
  • ggvis - interactive plots (behind the scenes, interactive plots are built with shiny)
  • dygraph - R interface to the dygraphs JavaScript charting library. It provides rich facilities for charting time-series data in R
  • Visualize Large Data
  • color palletes in R

Books with Rmarkdown

  • https://bookdown.org/yihui/bookdown/

Websites with Rmarkdown

Static sites (no need of databases, use of wordpress, etc.). Host for free on GitHub pages

  • https://www.rstudio.com/resources/webinars/introducing-blogdown/
  • https://slides.yihui.name/2017-rstudio-webinar-blogdown-Yihui-Xie.html
  • themes for hugo (a static site generator used by blogdown package)
    • find the one you like on this site https://themes.gohugo.io/
    • press Download - it should open a github address (if it is not GitHub it is ok..)
    • use this to install blogdown::install_theme(“user/repo”). It it is not on GitHub speicify hostname
    • fine tune the theme
    • host on GitHub pages or better in netfly
  • If you want to edit directly online, you can use this free service - cloudcannon. Also static webistes.

Additional Recommended Packages/triks

  • magick and EBImage - all kinds of image transformation, combination, animation, etc.
  • postr - making posters in R
  • profvis - profile the code: see which part of code runs longer
  • Adv. shiny tricks https://github.com/daattali/advanced-shiny
  • rMouse - control mouse
